'''Johnny Drummer''' (born '''Thessex Johns''', March 1, 1938) is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[soul blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[Keyboard instrument|keyboardist]], [[drummer]], [[harmonica]] player, and [[songwriter]].<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| pages= 145–6
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref> His [[stage name]] came after viewing the film, ''[[Johnny Guitar]]'', adopting the name to suit his then choice of [[musical instrument|instrument]].<ref name="Hanson"/> 

Drummer has released three albums.

==Life and career==
Drummer was born and raised in [[Alligator, Mississippi]], [[United States]], and first sang in his local church at the age of seven.  He visited his mother in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in 1954 and 1955, and joined the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] the following year. In addition to serving his country, Drummer learned to play the drums during his three-year period of duty.  By 1959, he had permanently relocated to Chicago, where he remains to the present.<ref name="Hanson"/>

In 1960, he joined a band containing [[Lovie Lee]] and [[Carey Bell]], and later played drums for about a year for [[Eddie King (musician)|Eddie King]].<ref name="Hanson"/>  After forming his own band, the Starliters, Drummer recorded a couple of tracks, "Lookin' For My Baby" and "I Can't Stop Twisting," with a local [[record label]], Wonderful Records, but these were never released.<ref name="Drummer">{{cite web |url=http://www.johnnydrummermusic.com/ |title=Meet Johnny Drummer |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Johnnydrummermusic.com |accessdate=December 10, 2011}}</ref>  In 1965, Drummer also recorded vocal [[overdubbing|overdubs]] on two tracks for [[Billy "The Kid" Emerson]], but these were also not issued.<ref name="Drummer"/> During the 1960s, the Starliters variously included [[Sammy Lawhorn]] and [[Eddie Shaw]]. Drummer also played on several of Eddie King's singles, and in 1965 once played with [[B.B. King]] at a concert when King's regular drummer did not arrive. Drummer was reluctantly  pressed forward in his own band's line-up to sing, and left regular drum playing to others.<ref name="Drummer"/>

In 1974, Drummer obtained full-time employment with the [[Chicago Police Department]], where he worked for twenty years.<ref name="Drummer"/>  However, he continued to play music in the evenings, having learned the rudiments of harmonica playing from [[Junior Wells]].<ref name="Hanson"/> In the latter part of that decade, Drummer recorded  "The Fire is Gone" and "I'll Find a Way," which were released as a single by [[Cobra Records|Abco Records]].<ref name="Drummer"/>  By 1985 Drummer had switched to playing the keyboards, and he and his band opened for many musicians including [[Denise LaSalle]], [[Z.Z. Hill]], [[Koko Taylor]], [[Tyrone Davis]] and [[Willie Mabon]].<ref name="Hanson"/>

His debut [[album]], ''It's So Nice'' was released on [[Earwig Music Company|Earwig]] in 1999.<ref name="Hanson"/> [[Cub Koda]] noted, "his knack for a catchy phrases and lyrical hooks coupled with funky grooves and solid instrumental mixes makes this album a real sleeper".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Cub Koda]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/its-so-nice-mw0000666848 |title=It's So Nice - Johnny Drummer | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> Subsequent album releases were ''Unleaded Blues'' (2001) and  ''Rockin' in the Juke Joint'' (2007).<ref name="AMG"/>
